sub_title: US health insurers doubled profits in second quarter amid pandemic
comment:
US Health insurers are bound by the Medical Loss Ratio (MLR) provisions in the Affordable Care Act (ACA).

Under these regulations they are required to spend .85c of every $1.00 they receive in premium payments on paying for medical services for their plan members.

This leaves .15c of premium revenue for all operating costs and profit.  Most plan's operating costs run between 10-13%.

Doubling profit as a raw number is one thing, but their margins remain relatively stable.  The only way for them to increase their margins is to decrease their administrative costs.

(They are also required to share back to all plan members any premium revenue less than .85 of every $1.00 spent.  E.g.  If a plan only spends .80c of every premium dollar on services for a given year, they split the .05c margin of revenue between all the plan members and send them a check.

My family has received a ~$1,500-3,000 reimbursement each year since this regulation went into effect, from Optima.)

They are essentially profit capped.  This article is kind of misleading.

Back in April we announced to all our members that anything COVID-related would be covered, no questions asked. You need to get tested? Covered. You tested positive and have to be in the hospital? Covered. Family member self-quarantined and you need medication delivered? Covered.

Abolish health insurance. They have always been unethical.  All those things they tell you Universal Health Care will do: death panels, delays in treatment, exorbitant cost, etc; they already do those things. 

Death Panels: They don't officially decide on cases. Instead, the the healthcare provider contacts them to find out if something is covered by your policy and then the insurance company decides if the treatment is something they have to pay for based on your policy. If they don't want to pay for it, that's fine. You still get the treatment right? But now you owe $5,000-$500,000 depending on the treatment out of pocket. This leads to the United States' most common cause of bankruptcy: medical debt. 

Delays in treatment: Hospitals and private practices get to pick which insurance companies they work with and accept. This means not every doctor will be able to accept your insurance, and if you like a certain doctor or need a treatment from a specialist, you'd better hope they are "in network". If not, you're spending time searching for a doctor and possibly having to travel far to get the doctor that accepts your insurance. Often, health insurance companies have a lot of customers in one area. Most people get health insurance through their employers, whom generally work with health insurance companies they've seen providing to other local companies in their area. Since there are a lot of people on the same coverage within one area, you're more likely to have to use the same doctors for treatment, which causes delays as they have to schedule you in.  Unless you're going to the emergency room, you likely have to wait weeks or months to get to see a doctor if you believe something is wrong with you. With UHC, you'd be able to pick any doctor you like, which barring a lack of choice for doctors in your area, should spread around and have shorter waiting periods.

[Exorbitant cost](https://www.daveabels.com/broken-bones-can-result-in-thousands-of-dollars-in-losses/#:~:text=If%20you%20suffer%20a%20broken,responsible%20for%20copayments%20and%20coinsurance.): Insurance companies use the model of being a middle man. They literally take money from you monthly (unless you're lucky enough that your employer pays all premiums), then act as a barrier for you receiving treatment without their permission. Because Healthcare Providers have to work with them, they have gotten to set prices for non-insured patients as a deterrent for not having insurance.  This is why a bag of Saline, which costs $2-5 to manufacture, costs between $60-250 to have administered. Perhaps you break your leg and you don't have insurance.  Good news! You get to owe the hospital $17,000-$35,000! Sure, you could say some of that is labor.  But in reality, it's price fixing between the insurance company and the hospital. The best part is that if the insurance *does* cover your treatment, they get to pay significantly less than you would have to. Typically barely above manufacturing costs, and almost always less than half of what you would have had to pay out of pocket.

This is terribly misleading from a forward-looking POV. 

Many in the comments have noted that P&C insurers are issuing refunds... health insurers will do the same; the refund calcs and regulations are not being reflected solely in Q2 earnings reports. It will come later as refunds are due to be paid to customers, employers, etc.

The companies are also offering other benefits to at-risk populations among their books. comment:
There is a LOT of misinformation in this thread.

Preface: I despise the current US health care model, and in no way want to be seen as a defender of it.

But, if the insurance companies make too much money, they'll have to pay back the extra anyway. One of the provisions in the Affordable Care Act was mandatory minimums on their Medical Loss Ratio. In other words the ratio of their income that must go to paying claims. For individual and small group plans, it's 80%. For large group sales, it's 85%.

If they aren't paying out claims, and their ratio drops below these, they are legally bound to issue rebates.

However, the process for doing so is also heavily regulated. I believe it is accessed annually (although I don't remember if it's the same date for all plans or based on what quarter the plan started or something). Point is, they can't just issue rebates whenever they want or it'll screw up their rate reviews with the government.

At the end of the day, they won't get to make gobs of money off of this. Not for long. 

Although if you really want to get into "how the sausage is made", they'll profit it in other ways. Insurance companies have to keep a regulated amount of "cash on hand" to pay out claims. Much like a bank cannot lend out 100% of their money at once. In the meantime they can invest those funds and earn profits from those investments. IIRC, those profits are not part of the MLR calculations, so they will make money from the excess income, then pay back the rebates later as needed.

I work for a nonprofit insurance company in Wisconsin. Couple reasons we‚Äôre turning a profit -

* Many providers stopped providing elective surgeries and treatments during the pandemic. Many have restarted, but these are cash cows for hospitals and major costs for insurance companies. 

* People, overall, are going out less. Telehealth appointments are becoming far more common and  a lot of hospitals charge a flat price for these - $20-40 per appointment compared to a traditional visit, which costs more. 

* Fewer people are reaching out for care. Part of it is fear of getting sick but also fear of cost. Layoffs have also had an impact as many are seeing cut and reduced coverage. 

* And finally, fewer people are hitting their deductibles. Usually, the profit margins begin to slide the closer you get to the end of the year - and this is important, because if this fall is as bad as they say it could be, those profits the media is telling you to get upset about may be what guarantees payment and coverage if you or a family member ends up in the ICU on a ventilator.
